sections.heading: Early Development (1991 - 1995)
content: 1991 â€“ Java was initiated as part of the Green Project by James Gosling, Mike Sheridan, and Patrick Naughton at Sun Microsystems.
Original goal: Create a platform-independent language for consumer electronics (like TVs, set-top boxes).
The language was initially called Oak, named after an oak tree outside Goslingâ€™s office.
1995 â€“ Oak was renamed Java, inspired by Java coffee from Indonesia, due to trademark issues.
Java was officially released as a core component of Sun Microsystems' Java Platform.

sections.heading: ðŸ”¹ Java Principles
sections.description: When Java was designed, the creators followed several key principles:

sections.heading: ðŸ”¹ Major Java Versions & Milestones
rows: Generics, annotations, and enhanced for-loop added.
Improved performance and scripting language support (JSR 223).
Try-with-resources, diamond operator, and NIO.2 added.
Lambda expressions, Stream API, new Date/Time API. Huge leap forward.
Java 11 became a Long Term Support (LTS) version.
Latest LTS with enhanced pattern matching, sealed classes, and more.

sections.heading: ðŸ”¹ Acquisition by Oracle
content: In 2010, Oracle Corporation acquired Sun Microsystems, and with it, the rights to Java. Since then, Oracle has managed Javaâ€™s development and licensing.

sections.heading: ðŸ”¹ Java Today
content: Java is still widely used in enterprise applications, Android development, web servers, financial services, and more.
Modern Java follows a 6-month release cycle for regular updates. Tools like Spring Boot, Hibernate, and Maven have become part of the Java ecosystem.
